short_description: Tunisia's signature fish couscous featuring fresh Mediterranean fish in a spicy tomato-based sauce. This coastal specialty showcases Tunisia's unique fusion of North African and Mediterranean flavors.
steps: Clean and cut fish into large steaks, season with salt.
In a couscoussier bottom, sauté garlic in olive oil.
Add tomato paste and harissa, cook for 2 minutes.
Add water, cumin, and bring to boil.
Add harder vegetables first (potatoes, carrots).
Steam couscous in the top section for 20 minutes.
Fluff couscous, add butter, steam again.
Add zucchini to the stew.
Gently add fish steaks, cook for 15 minutes.
Serve couscous topped with fish, vegetables, and spicy broth.
cooking_tips: Don't overcook the fish - it should be just flaky.
The harissa gives the characteristic Tunisian heat.
Serve with extra harissa on the side for those who like it spicy.
nutrition_benefits: Fish provides omega-3 fatty acids for heart health. The variety of vegetables adds vitamins and fiber. Harissa contains capsaicin which may boost metabolism.

short_description: A beloved Tunisian appetizer featuring a crispy malsouka pastry envelope filled with tuna, egg, and capers. The runny yolk inside creates a delightful surprise when you bite in.
steps: Drain tuna and mix with finely diced onion, capers, parsley, and harissa.
Lay out a pastry sheet and fold in half.
Place tuna mixture on one side.
Create a small well in the filling and crack an egg into it.
Carefully fold the pastry to form a triangle, sealing edges.
Heat oil to 180°C (350°F).
Gently slide brik into oil, fry until golden on both sides.
The egg yolk should remain runny inside.
Drain on paper towels.
Serve immediately with lemon wedges.
cooking_tips: Work quickly once you add the egg - it will start cooking.
The pastry should be thin and crispy, not chewy.
Eat immediately - brik doesn't keep well.
nutrition_benefits: Eggs provide complete protein and choline. Tuna offers omega-3s and lean protein. Capers add antioxidants and a distinctive briny flavor.

short_description: Tunisia's beloved street food breakfast - a warming chickpea soup served over torn bread, drizzled with olive oil and harissa. This humble dish is a staple on cold mornings across the country.
steps: Heat chickpeas in their cooking liquid or water until simmering.
Crush garlic with cumin and salt to form a paste.
Tear bread into bite-sized pieces in serving bowls.
Soft boil the eggs (6-7 minutes).
Ladle hot chickpeas and broth over the bread.
Add a spoonful of garlic-cumin paste and harissa.
Drizzle generously with olive oil.
Top with peeled soft-boiled eggs, halved.
Garnish with chopped preserved lemon and capers.
Mix everything together and eat immediately.
cooking_tips: Day-old bread absorbs the broth better than fresh.
Each person can customize their harissa and garlic levels.
The broth should be quite soupy.
nutrition_benefits: Chickpeas are excellent for fiber and plant protein. The combination with eggs provides complete protein. Cumin aids digestion.

short_description: A spicy Tunisian egg dish similar to shakshuka, featuring merguez sausages poached in a fiery tomato and pepper sauce. Perfect for brunch or a hearty dinner.
steps: Slice merguez and brown in a pan, set aside.
In the same pan, sauté diced onion and peppers.
Add minced garlic and caraway seeds.
Grate or dice tomatoes and add to pan.
Stir in harissa and simmer until sauce thickens.
Return merguez to the pan.
Make wells in the sauce and crack eggs into them.
Cover and cook until eggs are set but yolks still runny.
Serve directly from the pan with crusty bread.
cooking_tips: Use ripe, flavorful tomatoes for the best sauce.
Caraway seeds are essential for authentic flavor.
Don't stir after adding the eggs.
nutrition_benefits: High in protein from eggs and sausages. Tomatoes and peppers provide vitamins A and C. The spices may help boost metabolism.

short_description: Tunisia's beloved ring-shaped doughnuts, fried until golden and coated in sugar. These addictive treats are a popular street food, best enjoyed fresh and warm.
steps: Mix flour, yeast, sugar, and salt in a large bowl.
Add warm water gradually, mixing to form a soft, sticky dough.
Knead for 10 minutes until smooth and elastic.
Cover and let rise for 1 hour until doubled.
Heat oil to 180°C (350°F).
With wet hands, take portions of dough.
Stretch into a ring shape and drop carefully into oil.
Fry until golden brown on both sides.
Drain briefly and toss immediately in sugar.
Serve warm for the best experience.
cooking_tips: Keep your hands wet to prevent sticking.
The dough should be quite soft and stretchy.
Eat within a few hours - they don't keep well.
nutrition_benefits: A occasional treat providing quick energy. The simple ingredients make it a straightforward indulgence. Best enjoyed in moderation.
